hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Aun: I came to al-Sha'bi after the death of Ibrahim. He said to me: Were you among those who witnessed the burial of Ibrahim? I mentioned it to him. He said: By Allah, he did not leave behind anyone like him. When asked if it was in Kufa, he said: Not in Kufa, nor in Basra, nor in Syria, nor in such and such places. Muhammad ibn Abdullah added: nor in the Hijaz.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abjir: I informed al-Sha'bi of the death of Ibrahim. He said: I praise Allah, indeed he did not leave behind anyone like him. He was more knowledgeable while dead than while alive.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus: I heard Abu Bakr ibn 'Ayyash saying: Abraham al-Nakh'ai lived to about fifty years. Muhammad ibn Sa'd and others agreed that he died in the year ninety-six during the caliphate of al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik in Kufa, at the age of forty-nine, not having completed fifty. It was conveyed to me that Yahya ibn Said al-Qattan said: Abraham died at nearly fifty-five years old. Abu Nu'aym said: I asked the grandson of Abraham about his death, and he said: Four or five months after al-Hajjaj. Abu Nu'aym said: It seems he died at the beginning of the year ninety-six.

narrators.name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus
narrators.full_name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus al-'Ijli

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn 'Ayyash
narrators.full_name: Suleiman ibn Iyyas ibn 'Ayyash al-Harrani
reliabilityIssues: Poor memory in transmission from a distance
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Bakr ibn 'Ayyash, Suleiman ibn Iyyas

potential_issues.issue: Abu Bakr ibn 'Ayyash is classified as Saduq Sayyi' al-Hifz (truthful but with poor memory/recording)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith contains biographical information and reports about differing accounts of Ibrahim al-Nakh'ai's death date and age. Abu Bakr's poor memory affects the reliability of these numbers. The presence of multiple conflicting accounts (fifty vs. forty-nine vs. fifty-five years) within the hadith text itself indicates uncertainty even among classical scholars

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Awwam ibn Hawshab: I saw upon Ibrahim al-Taymi a red wrapper. It was also reported that the reason for Ibrahim al-Taymi's imprisonment was that al-Hajjaj was seeking Ibrahim al-Nakh'ai. The officer came and said: I want Ibrahim. Ibrahim al-Taymi said: I am Ibrahim, so he took him even though he knew he was seeking Ibrahim al-Nakh'ai. Ibrahim al-Taymi would not guide him to al-Nakh'ai, so he brought him to al-Hajjaj who ordered him imprisoned in the Dimasa (prison). They had no shade from the sun nor shelter from the cold, and every two were in a chain. Ibrahim changed (in appearance). His mother came to visit him in prison but did not recognize him until he spoke. He died in prison. Al-Hajjaj saw in his dream someone saying: A man from the people of Paradise died in this city tonight. When morning came, al-Hajjaj asked: Did anyone die last night in Wasit? They said: Yes, Ibrahim al-Taymi died in prison. He said: It is a dream, a suggestion from Satan, and ordered him thrown on the garbage heap.

narrators.name: Ishaq ibn Yusuf al-Azraq

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sufyan: About what motivated Ibrahim al-Taymi to do story-telling, he saw in a dream that he was distributing fragrant herbs. This reached Ibrahim al-Nakh'ai, who said: Fragrant herbs have a pleasant scent but a bitter taste.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibrahim al-Taymi: My father was wearing a simple cotton shirt with sleeves reaching to his wrists. I said to him: Father, why don't you wear better clothing? He said: I came to Basra and found thousands of dinars but I was not happy about them, nor did I think to return to them. I would have wished that every delicious food I ate would go into the mouth of the person I hated most. He said: I heard Abu al-Darda saying: Verily, the owner of two dirhams will have a more severe accounting on the Day of Resurrection than the owner of one dirham.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Khaithamah: A boy was born to my grandfather, so my grandfather named him Aziz. Then he came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: A boy has been born to me. He said: What have you named him? He said: Aziz. He said: Rather, his name is Abd al-Rahman. Khaithamah said: That is my father. In another chain: Narrated by Ibn Umar: The most beloved names to the Prophet ﷺ were Abdullah and Abd al-Rahman.
